qas.question: What was hunting regarded as in British India?
What does the Indian word "shikaris" mean in English?
What did British officers maintain whole corps of?
Why did the regals recruit low-ranking local tribes when hunting?

answers.text: because of their traditional knowledge of the environment and hunting techniques

qas.question: What could a Bengal tiger be hunted from the back of?
Where was hunting reguarded as a regal sport?
What is hunted from the back of an elephant?
Who were the shikaris headed by?
Why were low-ranking local tribes recruited?

answers.text: because of their traditional knowledge of the environment and hunting techniques

qas.question: What was shikari regarded as in British India?
What is the definition of maharaja?

plausible_answers.text: traditional knowledge of the environment and hunting techniques

qas.question: What two things were needed to successfully hunt an elephant?
What country had the largest population of elephants in the world?
Who did local tribes work with when taking down a Bengal tiger?

context: During the feudal and colonial times in <a5_0><b13_0>British India<b13_0/><a5_0/>, hunting was regarded as a <a0_0><b10_0>regal sport<b10_0/><a0_0/> in the numerous princely states, as many maharajas and nawabs, as well as British officers, maintained <b14_0>a whole corps of <a2_0><a7_0>shikaris<b14_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/> (<a1_0>big-game hunters<a1_0/>), who were <b11_0>native professional hunters<b11_0/>. They would be headed by a <a8_0>master of the hunt<a8_0/>, who might be styled mir-shikar. Often, they recruited the normally low-ranking local tribes <a3_0><a9_0>because of their <b12_0>traditional knowledge of the environment and hunting techniques<b12_0/><a9_0/><a3_0/>. Big game, such as <a6_0>Bengal tigers<a6_0/>, might be hunted from the back of <a4_0>an elephant<a4_0/>.
